content.raw: SSAO should also be disabled for sky rendering, see #2546.
content.html: SSAO should also be disabled for sky rendering, see #2546.

pull_request.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

update.description:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting. 

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see [PDF](https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2010/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO-doc.pdf) with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive. 

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene `<ambient>` values, and SSAO enabled (`ssao_plugin.world`), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect 

![ssao_world.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3388633340-ssao_world.jpg)

Here's `shapes.world` with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

![shapes_ssao.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1090205098-shapes_ssao.jpg)

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.
update.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

content.raw: updated to ignore objects with materials that use alpha rejection (materials that are part opaque and part transparent). 9c5f2d9
content.html: updated to ignore objects with materials that use alpha rejection (materials that are part opaque and part transparent). 9c5f2d9

pull_request.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

pullrequest.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

content.raw: There are other SSAO techniques in OGRE but they all require the `Modulate` and `GBuffer` compositors so I hard coded them. I had the idea that in the future we could integrate more SSAO techniques and let the users change these two params to select the effects they want.
content.html: There are other SSAO techniques in OGRE but they all require the Modulate and GBuffer compositors so I hard coded them. I had the idea that in the future we could integrate more SSAO techniques and let the users change these two params to select the effects they want.

pull_request.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

update.description:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting. 

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see [PDF](https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2010/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO-doc.pdf) with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive. 

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene `<ambient>` values, and SSAO enabled (`ssao_plugin.world`), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect 

![ssao_world.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3388633340-ssao_world.jpg)

Here's `shapes.world` with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

![shapes_ssao.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1090205098-shapes_ssao.jpg)

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.

content.raw:
I'm now getting a compilation error on xenial

~~~
plugins/AmbientOcclusionVisualPlugin.cc:184:43:
 error: ‘class Ogre::CompositionTechnique’ has no member named ‘getNumTargetPass’
     if (gBufCompInstance->getTechnique()->getNumTargetPass() > 1)
                                           ^
~~~

I'm now getting a compilation error on xenial

 error: ‘class Ogre::CompositionTechnique’ has no member named ‘getNumTargetPass’
     if (gBufCompInstance->getTechnique()->getNumTargetPass() > 1)
                                           ^

pull_request.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

update.description:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting. 

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see [PDF](https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2010/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO-doc.pdf) with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive. 

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene `<ambient>` values, and SSAO enabled (`ssao_plugin.world`), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect 

![ssao_world.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3388633340-ssao_world.jpg)

Here's `shapes.world` with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

![shapes_ssao.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1090205098-shapes_ssao.jpg)

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.
update.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin
